PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

2. Your address: INAGRAFTON AGE HOME MOOSE JAW PARK
3. Date: May 15-7-962
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Cricklade Rd. Box Hill
   Suburban Wilshire England
5. What was your father's name and occupation? ENOCH STROUD "FITTER"
   C.W.R.R. Railway (youself)
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): Sep-10-1906
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: PEARLS COURT, Weyburn, Ontario April 20
   171 CHAMBERS, ANNE Silverthorne, Toronto April 20
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I" was a small child," "I was 11 years old in my teens," etc.)
9. What were your reasons for coming West? 30 Years ago Jan 15
   To help to make a home and to encourage others that you can be happy and must try whenever you are working on the land and to help those who want to love to Palestine in Texas according to God we learned to love to Palestine in Texas according many happy children as Holy wrote the Bible. We spent many happy children as the years passed by.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) Through my relatives who lived in Ontario also the friends that had arrived on land our West. He had lived there near a town called Newell one of his brothers lived on the Kne drive Ranched and own the north of own farm from the Kne drive they would own the land and married a friend from 1932.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: MRS. ADELAIDE MARITHA CARTER
2. Your address: INAGRAFTON GAGE HOME HOUSE JAW PARK
3. Date: May 15-1962
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Cricklade Rd & Park Hill
   Alwooden, Wilshire England
5. What was your father's name and occupation? ENOCH STROUD "FITTER"
   C.W.R. Railway (Engineer)
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): S.A.C. 10-1906
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: EARLS COURT, Toronto Ontario April 20
   171 CHAMBERS, AVE Silverthorne Toronto
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I" was a small child," "I was a small child," etc.)
9. What were your reasons for coming West? To help make a home and to encourage others that you can live here and not be lonely and warm winter weather waiting on the land, and to help those who want to love to settle in Texas according to God's will and the land's promise.
10. How did you learn about the West? Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information? Through my relatives who lived in Canada in Ontario also the friends that had visited or lived out West. He had lived there nearly 3 years after his marriage to our farm in the divide between the two farms. The man who married a friend from England until his death in 1931.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? 

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)? Alone.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Railway CPR.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

I was deeply impressed by the prairie scene. It touched me at Winnipeg. There one in a dune stands out in my mind when the train with its hard wooden seats around the conductor platform goes over a mound of yellow sand. I knew the conductor and each one could not go on that if they knew the other had been there before. We went on the train and all remained in our seats until we came to the end of the line. The way was very rough and the train was very fast.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

After arriving at Assiniboia (13th day) we went to the Yellow Grass Sack where we were provided with food and shelter by the river. We were arranged for further travel by a Mr. Lea who was our guide. He had been a missionary for many years and we were quite pleased with him.

16. Where did you settle or take up land in the FORWARD District?

We bought the farm in Oct. 4th 1944 to live in Ceylon SASK.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

As a Domestic Servant; I had (a) two good homes during years of service; I was a farmer's wife; and enjoyed seeing the work done on the farms. I have more guests now than ever before. I am happy in this new home and enjoy the life here.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? Very enthusiastic and supportive.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? Alone.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Railway CPR.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.) I was deeply impressed by the vast plains changing from green to yellow as we traveled westward. We encountered snowstorms and harsh weather conditions, but we persevered.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? At the Adams Beach Hotel in Regina.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? We bought land near Ceylon, SASK.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

As a Domestic Servant; I had two good homes during years of service.

Here in Saskatchewan, I have more space, more room for the wonderful development of west Canada, and the wonderful opportunity to work hard and live in comfort. I am happy in this new environment and am looking forward to a bright future.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

---

My husband came out but did not settle even wanted to take me back, considered the Barrie settlement to be too tough for a lady. Naturally I remained with my husband and tried to make the best of things. Who could have thought times like these would ever happen again?

The most exciting was to get a meal good from in 1916 and a good well of water within sight of the house. We also had a nice quilt made by my girl after the war. We were very pleased with our new stove.

We went for transportation 20 miles to Yellow Grass Lake, then having a wrestling match, you wish a team you a trip, also another good event of course it was. We visited Washwood who was another good neighbor, also the women were improved hand controlled but what a gem! Also the women were from a place called through was a good one from them also.

---

Settled in Cypress Saddle 1910

J.F. Eaton Co., Toronto, Ontario, For Clothing

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? Municipal of Pangman, 1940 in the fall

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

I decided I would never leave my home learning things and surroundings to do my best as I knew it was better. You see very difficult, especially living in the north. The winter weather was very harsh and difficult to survive. I was working in the mines and was exposed to all kinds of weather conditions. However, my boss did not offer me any other job as a result, they were forced to work as a result.
25. When was the first car used in the community? 1911 Ford. 5 Seaters.

One daughter Mrs. E. Carter & family, Swift Current, Saskatchewan.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came here?

Wear? In the fall, we wore overcoats, boots, and hats. We also wore gloves and scarves.
